docs.lead_paragraph: For Bill Bradley the day began with a radio interview in which he repeatedly declined to criticize Vice President Al Gore, his rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, telling his host that he believed such attacks undercut democracy and weakened his appeal as a candidate for national office.

headline.main: Bradley's Quandary: To Attack Gore or Not?

docs.abstract: Bill Bradley's sharp attacks against Vice Pres Al Gore during their debate in Manchester seem to make it clear that campaign is moving into more aggressive phase as it enters final days before New Hampshire primary (M)
docs.snippet: For Bill Bradley the day began with a radio interview in which he repeatedly declined to criticize Vice President Al Gore, his rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, telling his host that he believed such attacks undercut democracy and...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Allan Zarkin came looking for work, Merle Hoffman could not have been happier. She and the doctor had worked together off and on for many years in her clinic, Choices Women's Medical Center in Queens. Moreover, her medical director had just left, so she happily handed the title over to Dr. Zarkin on Nov. 1. What she said she did not know was that the doctor had been dismissed just weeks before from Beth Israel Medical Center for what may be the most bizarre incident in the history of the hospital.

headline.main: How Doctor Got Work After Carving Into Patient

docs.abstract: Article discusses how Dr Allan Zarkin was able to find employment at abortion clinic after being dismissed from Beth Israel Medical Center for carving his initials into stomach of patient on whom he had just performed Caesarean section; patient, Dr Liana Gedz, is suing hospital, Dr Zarkin and his former medical practice for $5.5 million; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When Dr. Allan Zarkin came looking for work, Merle Hoffman could not have been happier. She and the doctor had worked together off and on for many years in her clinic, Choices Women's Medical Center in Queens. Moreover, her medical director had just...

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and EDWARD WONG

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing questions about the vigor of his campaign and under frequent attack from Vice President Al Gore, former Senator Bill Bradley attacked Mr. Gore tonight over abortion, welfare reform, health care plans that ''nibble around the edges'' and for working ''hand in glove with special interests.'' In their seventh and most combative debate, held just six days before the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Gore hammered Mr. Bradley on familiar subjects, accusing him of voting with President Ronald Reagan against children and of offering a health plan that did not do what it promised.

headline.main: Two Democrats Fire Broadsides In Testy Debate

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidates Al Gore and Bill Bradley hold their seventh and most combative debate six days before New Hampshire primary; Bradley, facing questions about vigor of his campaign and under frequent attack from Gore, attacks Gore for his positions on abortion, welfare reform, health care and for working with special interests; Gore accuses Bradley of voting with Pres Ronald Reagan against children and of offering health plan that does not do what it promises; each candidate accuses other of conducting negative campaign, and Bradley even raises specter of Pres Richard M Nixon; photo of Gore before debate in Manchester, NH (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders said today that they would soon create a group of about a dozen Republican lawmakers to draft legislation providing coverage of prescription drugs for Medicare beneficiaries. The step comes as millions of elderly people are complaining that they cannot obtain or afford the drugs they need.

headline.main: House Republicans to Draft Bill On Medicare Prescription Drugs

docs.abstract: House Republican leaders say they will create group of about dozen Republican lawmakers to draft legislation providing coverage of prescription drugs for Medicare beneficiaries (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Nassau County struggles to become solvent, a county audit released today found that a Freeport day care center overcharged the government by $482,000 while spending money on Broadway tickets, Champagne and expensive perquisites for the family members of its executive director. County Comptroller Frederick E. Parola said his auditors had found what he called ''an appalling pattern of financial abuses and mismanagement'' at the Sunflower School, a day care center in Freeport partly financed by the county. Mr. Parola said he planned to forward the audit to the Nassau County district attorney's office to determine if there had been any criminal wrongdoing.

headline.main: Audit Finds Financial Abuses At a Nassau Day Care Center

docs.abstract: Nassau County Comptroller Frederick E Parola releases county audit that finds that Sunflower School, Freeport day care center headed by Merle Clarke, overcharged government by $482,000 while spending money on Broadway tickets and other expensive perquisites for Clarke's family; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ABOUT a year ago, I cornered a group of eminent college and university presidents. A major study of the impact of race-sensitive admission policies at selective colleges and universities had just been published. It asserted that affirmative action at those institutions had played an important role in bolstering the black middle class. All of the assembled thought that was good news.

headline.main: Timid at the Top: A Question of Leadership

docs.lead_paragraph: Al Gore wants to be the person who says how things go. But if you wanna be boss, you gotta be willing to whack some people. You gotta get Bill Bradley to donate his kneecaps. You gotta put your (expletive) rivals in a Luca Brasi situation. Bradley may have run Jersey once, but he was never a made guy in the administration. He never reached the heights. So Al Gore is hardening his position. Bradley can show some (expletive) respect and drop out . . . or it's gonna be a rainy night in Lyndhurst.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column on Al Gore adding verbal toughness to his touchy-feely campaign in Iowa; explains that this year's Presidential race, despite posturing about civility, is really about George W Bush's desire to avenge his father's loss in 1992, and Bill Clinton's hope of avenging himself on Republicans (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: He bit his lip as he rose, his hands fumbling on the table and the butterflies careering around his stomach, but then Kris Cunard looked around at his neighbors' faces and just let the words tumble out. ''Steve Forbes is unapologetic in his pro-life positions,'' said Mr. Cunard, an insurance salesman. ''I have to vote my conscience, and to me that's the most important thing.''

headline.main: Shy Neighbors Debate And Look for Meaning On a Night of Voting

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bradley and Doctor Say Bouts Are No Worry,'' about Bill Bradley's heart problems (news article, Jan. 22):
docs.abstract: Dr Richard D Amelar letter asks whether Bill Bradley, with his irregular heart beat, would encounter any difficulty now if he were to apply for million-dollar health and disability insurance policy
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Bradley and Doctor Say Bouts Are No Worry,'' about Bill Bradley's heart problems (news article, Jan. 22):

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite concerns among some aides about the state of his campaign, former Senator Bill Bradley said today that he was more convinced than ever that the course he chartered for his presidential campaign more than a year ago was fundamentally correct. In recent weeks, Mr. Bradley's insurgent campaign has been battered by negative news coverage and falling poll numbers, and many political analysts have argued that he has not been sharp enough in drawing distinctions with Mr. Gore or aggressive enough in responding to the vice president's repeated attacks. Mr. Bradley ended up with 35 percent of the vote, compared with Mr. Gore's 63 percent.

headline.main: Bradley Says Campaign Is on the Right Path

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidate former Sen Bill Bradley says he is more convinced than ever that course of campaign is fundamentally correct despite concern among some aides; insurgent campaign has been battered in recent weeks by negative news coverage and falling poll numbers; many political analysts say Bradley has not been sharp enough in drawing distinctions with Vice Pres Gore or aggressive enough in responding to Gore's repeated attacks; Bradley ended up with 35 percent of vote, compared with Gore's 63 percent in Iowa caucuses; photo (M)
